WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN FARMERS EAT?
A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name Mrs. H. G. Langley
Address
Birthplace Scotland - Peterhead - Aberdeenshire

1. INDUSTRY QUESTIONS
What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? May 1902
Where did you set up housekeeping? Whitewold, Regina area
Where had you been living before that? Scotland
For how many people did you prepare meals? 7
How far was it to your nearest store? 16 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? About a week
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
Sugar, tea, flour, rolled oats, coffee, prunes syrup, dried apples. In 1904 we moved to the area we now reside which was 50 miles from Saskatoon or 40 miles from Battleford. There was no railroad then nor northern Saskatoon.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS
What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Saskatoon Champion
In what quantities did you buy it? 100 lbs
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $1.98
How much did you use graham flour? about 20 lbs
Whole wheat flour? about 20 lbs
Was flour milled locally? No, far away? Regina, that year? 1904
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? $1.35
What other grain products did you use?
Cornmeal? No Whole wheat? Farina?
Other?

Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes
How did you grind it? With the shoffer which ground grain for the stock. We ran it two or three times through the mill until it was as fine as we desired. We found that Garnet wheat made the best porridge having less gluten the porridge was less sticky and had a better flavor.
Langley, H.G.
Spores. 1902

1. PERIODIC HISTORY
   What year did you start homesteading in Eastern Canada? May 1903.
   Where did you set up housekeeping? Whitewater, Ontario.
   How far was it to your nearest store? About 5 miles.
   How often could a visit be made to the store? Once or twice a week.
   What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
   Sugar, tea, flour, rolled oats, coffee, brown sugar,
   dried apples. In 1904 we moved to the area we now reside.

   In what quantities did you buy it? 100 lbs.

   Was flour called locally? No, far away!
   That was the price for a twenty pound bag. $1.98.
   What other grain products did you use?
   Cornmeal? Yes, whole wheat?
   Oats?

Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes.
How did you grind it? With the help of a hand grinding mill.
We found that Gurnett wheat made the best flour.
Flour ground from the homestead grown wheat had a better flavor.
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 30 lbs.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? $1.40

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Lily Golden Syrup

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 10 lb.

At what price? 20 cents

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? Milked cows and cows.

Butter? Churned. Eggs? From our own flock.

What was the price of butter? Sold at 15¢/lb or eggs? 12¢/dozen.

Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes. How? Lime water.

Did you make butter? Yes. Cheese? Yes.

What kind of cheese? Cheddar.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Purchased from neighbors.

How did you get fresh meat? Purchased from neighbors.

How often did you get fresh meat? Not in summer.

How did you preserve meat? Pickled and frozen.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Yes.

If so what year was it organized? Operated continuously since 1915.

Did you use game? Yes. What kinds? Pheasants, ducks, geese.

For how long? During the open season.

What part did fish play in the family diet? Mainly used in winter when traders would bring wagon loads of frozen fish.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Fresh.

Kinds? Jacks, white, suckers.

How far was this water from your home? 3 miles.

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) Barrel.

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

When money & time was available wells were dug from 1908 on. Now most farmers have soft water systems for laundry purposes using the well water for cooking & drinking. Dug outs are a further source of water supply for stock & supplementing laundry purposes when rain fails.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

No. In 1906-1907 trains were delayed by storms. Coal oil ran short so we were reduced to using fat to give us light. We put melted fat in a saucer & used rag for a wick. Fat became scarce so neighbors shared around. Roads were very bad & trips to town were few & far between.

20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

There is very little difference, other than we have a greater variety of food to choose from home-canning, etc. We now have a quick freeze cold storage plant giving most people an ample supply of fresh meat, whereas kitchens are better equipped or more convenient.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of home grown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

Since the 1940s we have bought bacon instead of curing our own & buy bread chiefly because our family is reduced from 6 to 3.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. [Use back of page if more space is needed].

We moved to this district in 1904. At that time there was no railroad. Our nearest store and P. Office was Great Bend about 20 miles from us. We made the trip weekly. We milked 20 cows at that time. The butter we made we took to the store & traded for groceries. You can imagine how hard it was to deliver butter in good condition in the hot weather driving 20 miles in a wagon. We made the butter into 1 lb. points. Butter was in short supply so the store keeper had no difficulty in disposing it to the many farming homesteaders. The price was 25¢ in summer.

In Whitehead from 1902 to 1904 we packed the butter in 25-lb wooden pails. This was shipped by the store keeper and we received 15¢ per lb during the summer.
21. When did you begin to rely on pure and fresh foods and organic forms instead of canned or preserved foods? (Give us any details and dates at possible.)

Since the 1940s we have bought between indeed buying our own a buy bread shilly because our family is reduced from 6 to 3.
